item.title: Flagship Professional Services Website
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
Lawyer, doctor, dentist, plumber, artist. You need a flagship professional services website. I get asked all the time about these types of websites, and I'll explain the nuts and bolts to you right now.
WordPress - You want a WordPress website. There really isn't an argument here, WordPress is what you want. The top reasons are: it's free forever it's secure free e-commerce most number of professionals on the platform - This is one of the main reasons professionals should choose WordPress. Simply put, when it comes time to hire tech people to work on your site, there are more people who know this software than any other software. It powers up to 30% of all websites on the internet. Your nephew probably knows how to run a WordPress website.
Design Design is what your website looks like. The layout, graphics, colors scheme, and fonts. This is what your theme does. You have several options. First of all, if you are technically or artistically inclined at all, play around with the free themes in the .org repo. They are the most secure themes, and they are free. Do not purchase a premium theme! They are a complete ripoff. If feel like designing your website is too tough a challenge for you, and it is for most businesses, you should run a design contest on a site like freelancer or upwork. $300 will get you great results. Don't pay $1000, run three $300 week long contests back to back. Require HARD CODED HTML - NOTHING ELSE WILL DO.

item.title: Perfect WordPress plugin development workflow
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
There are at least several types of WordPress development: content, front-end theme development, and backend plugin development. This article discusses backend plugin development, and a cheap, buletproof workflow.
Make your plugin environment agnostic WordPress works on lots of different systems. A "plugin" should be able to, well, plug in. Your code should go in a plugin, and not a theme, so that it works on any site, or environment. Never hard code URLs.
Use Git Git is the industry standard way of distributing and working on code. You can simply use Github or Bitbucket, and even put the code behind a password firewall if it needs to stay private.
Use a 3 tier deployment architechure Each programmer has to have a physical machine to work on. This can be in the cloud, or a phyical device like a laptop, but it must conceptually exist. I personally use an Ubuntu laptop, but it could just as easily be a shared cloud server. Programmers and developers work on their local machine, and when they are ready to commit, they commit to the git server. If you use a common git service like Github or Bitbucket, you can use webhooks to deploy automatically to the staging server. I use servers oni Amazon AWS that have obscure domain names like aws-ec2-334-c3.com . They are super cheap, easy to deplyThe staging server is a duplicate of the production server, which is public facing. The project leader then manually pulls from git repo to the production server once everything check out on staging.

item.title: WordPress plugin developer workflow
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
Are you developing plugins for WordPress? Here is a basic workflow that provides:
  • fully testable code
  • access control for outsourcers
  • separation of code from data
  • continuous integration

Git

Code should be stored in a git repo, and published to a central repository. You can use one of the two major repos for free. Use github if your code is open source or you don't care who sees it, use bitbucket if you want to put it behind a password.

Servers

Programmers can work on whatever type of machine they like. Some developers recommend using some kind of system to sync the data between environments. For instance using VVV or a some other virtual machine. When you are developing a plugin, you should not rely on this type of system. Instead, create the plugin to work in any environment, any machine. Don't hard code URLs. If there is data that is relevant to the plugin's development, it should be coded into your tests. For instance, say your plugin needs some specific permalink structure to work. One way to handle the situation, is to setup a WordPress machine with the specific structure, and allow the team access to this server. Instead, place the requirement in the code itself. Don't rely on pre-set database settings. I, personally have a high speed Ubuntu laptop I work on. If a person doesn't have access to a machine, you can spin one up in the cloud for pennies. This script will launch a dev server on AWS and setup everything you need to develop. It comes with a pre-loaded IDE [Codeiad] so programmers don't even need Eclipse or PHPStorm, just a browser!

item.title: Security flaw in WordPress
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
A valid use case: There is a business value to the use case pattern on many platforms where a confirmation email is sent, and then an encrypted or nonced link must be clicked to perform an action. The value of the features is:
The pattern confirms the user receiving the email has credential access to the receiving email account, reducing SPAM, and increasing security.
When you signup for Facebook, they send you an email with a link to confirm your account before it become active. This proves to Facebook that the recipient email is alive, and the http user requesting the account has recipient credentials for the email account. This seams to be the intended purpose behind this new feature as of 4.9, as well as providing additional security to the system. My contention is that this is a confused purpose, and in fact renders WordPress LESS secure. This feature is ill conceived and should be completely rolled back. Ultimately however, it's simply a design choice. I am a plugin dev, not a core dev. My challenge to the core dev team is to at least acknowledge the ramifications of the design choice. There is another, trivial value* This flow prevents against typos. However, that logic fails in that there are many other settings that are more important that should be protected against typos this way. Why isn't the site title emailed to the admin?

Implied Workflow is different on multisite versus single site

As will be shown, the new feature actually requires two user roles: an installing admin and a post-instal-admin, and these roles have different capabilities. cap#1: the capabilitiy to set the site email without confirmation. cap#2: the ability to set it with confirmation. It is my contention this is not clearly understood. The error comes from the fact that in multisite, there are in fact two roles: super admin, and regular administrator. These roles usually coincide with the different capabilties. Under most work flows using multisite, there is a peer class [usually one induvidual user per site per class, but it could be many users] of users that defines these implied roles. In other words, on multisite, usually there is one super admin, and one regular admin per domain, and the fact that this feature requires two different sets of capabilities wasn't noticed before because there are in fact two user types in multisite. On single site, there are just "administrators" - one peer class of users with the same [or they SHOULD be the same] capabilities. My contention is that this new feature creates an illogical jumble of the capabilities in single site, and this was not noticed because the bifiracaption wasn't noticed on multisite [where the feature came from].

Misunderstanding of the primogenial role

This new feature was added because:
On a multisite installation it's not possible to change the Email Address setting on a site without first clicking the confirmation link that gets emailed to the new address. This same behaviour should be implemented on regular single site installations to avoid the address being inadvertently set to an incorrect address.
The feature author seams to misunderstand the difference between the user roles vis-a-vi a regular WordPress install and a multisite install. An administrator in a single site install is the primogenial user, and there can be many peer admins of equal capability on the site. As will be shown, there is no technical restrictions on the admin role in the single site install, which is not true for multi site installs, even though they can both run arbitrary code. There are explicit and implied role capability differences. For instance, one implied difference is that on a multisite install, a regular admin cannot instantiate the installation of the network, only the super admin can do this. In a multisite install, it might make sense [although I would disagree], to have a regular admin [although this person can run still run arbitrary code] to confirm an email is existent to the super admin. However, on a single site, this feature is asking one of many equal admins to confirm the existence of the email to one of any other equal admins, including himself. There is a major difference between the two concepts, and there is no connection between the user who controls the site email, and the admin who requests or confirms the change. You can have many admins, but usually there is only one human in control of one email. On a multisite install, the super admin or the regular administrator have both explicit and implicit differences in their capabilities. This new feature creature unconsidered implicit differences in the user role capablities of explicitly equal users. As will be shown, this misunderstanding creates two new implied admin roles, the "installing-admin" and the "post-install-admin", which have different capabilities, although this does not seam to be intended, is not explicit, and in undesired. It also requires the coordination of two human beings to change a site setting on a single site WordPress install, in the case where one admin wants to give control of the site email to another admin. A false sense of security in the presence of arbitrary code To run "arbitrary code" means essentially to be able to do anything possible. In WordPress, this is represented as the ability to install plugins in the "administrator" role. A logged in user who can run arbitrary code is completely unrestricted, and can be in no way technically constrained by ANY security feature or audit, besides operating system level techniques. If there are settings that require a certain level of authority to change, that setting shouldn't be shown to a user who ins't authorized to change the setting. For instance, a subscriber is never shown a choice to add a new theme. The inverse of this is also true. The system should not tell a user that they cannot change a setting, when they in fact can. It provides a false sense of security for the setting. When you tell an admin he can't change a setting without having outbound email access and recipient email credentials [in the 4.9 flow, you have to have access to outbound email and access to the receiving email to change the site email], it might be implied that this is actually true. In fact, the admin can run arbitrary code, therefore he CAN change the setting. without the email confirmation. There should never be an implied restriction on a user who can run arbitrary code, because it is a false restraint. This new feature creates the only case of this I am aware of: a user being show a setting, and being told he can't change it, but still being allowed to run arbitrary code. Installing WordPress without outbound email and the bifrcation of the admin role within three seconds: This feature was adopted to extend a feature in WordPress Multi-Site. This feature, adopted from multisite WordPress, requires two separate roles to execute. In multisite, this isn't a problem since there are super admins and regular administrators. This does not seam to have been considered when moving the feature from multisite to single site. It doesn't seem to be considered that when WordPress is installed, this setting could be entered without the system having access to outgoing email in the first place. For instance, if you install WordPress on localhost, the user is asked to enter the email, AND IT IS NOT CONFIRMED. You don't need outgoing email access or recipient credentials to do the "Ready Sparky" install on localhost. However, once the install is complete, that same user is then restricted - three seconds later - from changing the site email because the site doesn't have outgoing email access. This would be a new restriction as of 4x, and the only setting like this. Maybe this is by design. The thought might be that the installing admin could enter the site email without confirmation, and then that same user must - from that point on - have outgoing email setup and recipient email access. OK, well maybe that's important, but it's not true! Because this same user has the ability to run arbitrary code. So if the desire is to allow a user to install WordPress and enter an email, and THEN restrict that same user from changing the same setting three seconds later, it should actually prevent the user from doing so. By having this one off system to confirm this one setting, it implies that the admin is actually somehow prevented from changing the site email without clicking the confirmation link. In reality, he just needs to know a little PHP, since he can run arbitrary code. There is no other setting like this. It seams to bifracate the admin role. Maybe there should be an "installing-admin" role, and a "post-install-admin". The "installing-admin" should have certain capabilties, and the post-install-admin can have different capabilities. The first can set the site email to anything he wants, but the "post-install-admin" must have email recipient credentials to change the site email? However, I don't think this is a decent feature, again since both of them can run arbitrary code. Let's say you are a "post-install-admin" of a WordPress site [not user #1], and you try to change the email. As of 4x you'd discover you would need to have recipient credentials for the receiving email to change the address, as well as having setup outbound email. You might therefore assume that the current site email has actualy been confirmed in the past this way. However, that isn't true. What is true, are that there are two types of admins: the admin who created the site, and any admins later added. This is an implied truth in WordPress since you cannot delete user #1. However, it isn't explicit that user #1 has the ability to create a site with a false admin email [and on the first try only!], but only he has that ability. Admin #2 would have to have recipient credentials, and could never setup a false site email. He mght therefore beleive Admin #1 also had this restriction, when he didn't. Imagine a large organization where a user was promoted from role editor to admin. That user would never have the ability to change the site email without having recipient credientials. In fact, most WordPress admins are in this category, since most sites are setup by sysadmins by hosting companies like GoDaddy. This feature creates the impression that the site email is somehow secured by having a confirmation link clicked in the past. However, the truth is that it could have been a totally false email set by the installing admin. And THIS is by design, since WordPress can be setup in many funky configs, say localhost, single page apps, IOT etc. A secondary admin would not be exposed to this, and would probably be confused. It seams implied to the second admin, that since he cannot set the site email without outbound email access and recipient email access, that the first admin also is restricted thus. There is a similiar program flow when administrators enter the emails of users, for instance when they add a new user. However, that flow isn't confused, because there is a checkbox for the admin to prevent the email from going out. In other words, the admin can enter a user email without confirmation. Why Transient data Security Issue: Presumably, one of the reasons to change a site email has something to do with security. It is changing from one email to another. Perhaps from a developer's personal email to a site's permanent public email. This feature creates a situation where an ephemeral transient is created in the database that insn't intuatively exposed to the user. When an admin changes the email, during the time between when he does the action, and when he switches to his email and clicks the confirmation email, there is this transient state where the incipant email is stored in the database at a time when it is not the site's actual email. This time period could be anything. So the old, presumably dead email, is stored in the database unencrypted, or the new email depending on how you look at it. In anycase there are timese when TWO emails are in the database, and it's not clear to all the admins or the system when this time is or how long it existed. Whatever percieved security benifits this feature might acrue, having this transient exist seams like a bad idea. Maybe a database snap shot is taken at that exact instant, and the admin's development email is captured in a database backup? This feature creates the situation of a transient peice of data about a dead email being stored in the database for at least some human ammount of time for no reason. Doesn't seam like a good idea. It is a design choice, and in my opinion a mistake. I'll be satisfied and leave you to you'al it if we can at least explicitly decide that this choice is being made consciously: That the "site email" will require outbound email and recipient credentials to CHANGE the email, but NOT to set it up. That this reality would only be known to a sysadmin who installs the system. That a second admin, with identical abilities to admin #1, could NOT intentionally set a non confirmed site email, but the installing admin COULD have intentionally set a non confirmed email. The same user who is the installing admin can setup any site email upon instalation, including an unconfirmed email, but cannot change the email three seconds later. That this is the only setting like this. That the normal use case is to confirm the recipient email, but that in our case the user who is entering the email is the same user who needs to confirm it [an admin who can run arbitrary code]! That we are relying on an outside service to correct for a typo in ONE setting only. That this entire system has been created in the context of a user who has the ability to run arbitrary code. Similiar to the user email change system, but one of a kind bad encryption WordPress uses two main types of encryption, the Portable PHP password hashing framework [for hashing passwords], and the WordPress nonce https://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_Nonces system. There is a similiar feature to the one introduce in 4x, that WordPress uses when a user initiates a change in email request. That feature emails the new recipient email a confirmation link, which must then be clicked in order to compleate the user email change. While these two features might seam similiar, they use compleately different systems to generate the activation link. The user email change system uses the standard WordPress nonce system. The site email change system uses a one of a kind, one off MD5 encryption system to generate the link. The nonce is a WordPress standard, which is subject to extensibility and upgrade, while the new feature's encryption acivation system is a one developer show, created especially for this feature. Not only is it a one of a kind, one author encryption technique; it is an insecure and unsophisticed method. A one of a kind method for a critical system setting! The new feature uses an unsecure MD5 encryption in the link. This is NOT the same system that is used for the email change link that users can use. That feature is totally different and uses the nonce system. The new feature uses a one off system that creates it's own encryption mechanism. This is not extensible. Why not use the regular nonce system on this action? If we imagine there is an action called "change_site_email" [assuming it's this new feature, and we're not talking about the old way, which could - and should - be put into a regular API action], it would be impossible to create a valid nonce for this action. Logically impossible to use WordPress nonce for this action The nonce system requires a logged in user. There is no connection between the logged in user, and the person who controls the site email [which must be controlled in order to click the new activation link]. There can be multiple admins, but only one site emial. Who knows which admin controls the site email. For instance, the site email might be: admin1@site.com and it might be changed to: admin2@site.com There are two admins, and the goal is for admin2 to get the sites emails. It requires the two human beings to physically co-ordinate their actions, and rely on out third party comunications service, in order to complete the action of transfering the site email from one person's email address to anothers. To make matters worse, the text of the email being sent is personally addressed to a person, using the first name of the sending admin. So when admin1 changes the email to one controlled by admin2, the email is still adressed to admin1. This is because when the first admin initiates the change, he doesn't have access to the second admin's email. Therefore he cannot compleate the transfer. This creates the problem of both emails being held in an enencrypted transient option in the database. Until the second admin clicks the link, the first admin is FORCED to keep getting the site's emails. There is no record kept of this transaction, and no limit on the time that these transients can be help in the database. nonce requires a logged in user. In the case of changing the site's email, it's not clear what user is in control of the email account. It could be any Possible resolution: We could have a check box like in the "add user" section, something like "Send a confirmation email". This invalidates the purported reason of adding security to the setting, but this is invalidated anyway because of the arbitrary code issue. It would however, fix the typo issue. This just seams like bloat to me. Typos Perhaps the point is to prevent typos. OK, but it seams to me this is radical overkill to control typos on this one setting. It's not even the most important setting! At least the site url has to be a more important setting, and therefore should be locked down for typos this way.

item.title: A valid use case for confirmation emails
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
There is a business value to the use case pattern on many internet platforms where a confirmation email is sent, and then an encrypted or nonced link must be clicked to perform the confirmation action. The value of the features is:
The pattern confirms the user receiving the email has credential access to the receiving email account, reducing SPAM, and increasing security.
When you signup for Facebook, they send you an email with a link to confirm your account before it become active. This proves to Facebook that the recipient email is alive, and the http user requesting the account has recipient credentials for the email account. This seams to be the intended purpose behind the admin email confirmation feature as of 4.9, as well as providing additional security to the system. My contention is that this is a confused purpose, and in fact renders WordPress LESS secure for several reasons. Similiarity to the add user feature When a user registers for a WordPress site, a confirmation email is sent to him from the site, to confirm the user has access to the email. This valid use case, is identical to the one used by facebook.com, described above. It is the confirmation of some information between two human groups / persons [the stakeholders of the site, and the user who is trying to register]. It is important to understand: THIS IS NOT A SECURITY FEATURE! An administrator can run arbitrary code. There is a check box available for administrators to override the outbound email: [caption id="attachment_15594" align="alignnone" width="1366"] confirm_user_email_being_sent[/caption] Why can't this emial be a true security feature? In computer science, there is a concept called "arbitrary code". A user who can run arbitrary code can literally do anything on the system, and can't be restricted.

item.title: Implied role structure on multisite versus single site
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
In WordPress 4.9 a new feature was added where a confirmation email is sent when an administrator tries to change the site email. In WordPress, the ultimate role is administrator. There is a flag for an As will be shown, the new feature actually requires three seperate user roles: an installing-admin, a change-initiator-post-install-admin, change-completor-post-install-admin, and these can be different users with different implied capabilities, although this doesn't seam to have been considered.
Role
installing-admincan set site admin email without confirmation
post-install-admin
cap#1: the capabilitiy to set the site email without confirmation. cap#2: the ability to set it with confirmation. It is my contention this is not clearly understood. The error comes from the fact that in multisite, there are in fact two roles: super admin, and regular administrator. These roles usually coincide with the different capabilties. Under most work flows using multisite, there is a peer class [usually one induvidual user per site per class, but it could be many users] of users that defines these implied roles. In other words, on multisite, usually there is one super admin, and one regular admin per domain, and the fact that this feature requires two different sets of capabilities wasn't noticed before because there are in fact two user types in multisite. On single site, there are just "administrators" - one peer class of users with the same [or they SHOULD be the same] capabilities. My contention is that this new feature creates an illogical jumble of the capabilities in single site, and this was not noticed because the bifiracaption wasn't noticed on multisite [where the feature came from].

item.title: Wordpress Plugin: CRG FastRegister
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded: Try it, just enter your email into the Sign Up for My Newsletter box on the right! WordPress has a very clunky registration system. First the user gives their email, then the system emails them a code, then the user has to copy and paste the code to login. A simpler solution is to trust the user about their email on their first login, and then just log them in. This plugin creates a sidebar widget that asks for the user's email. If they enter a new email, they immediately get logged in. If they enter an existing email, they are forwarded to the standard login page with their email already filled out. This plugin does away with "user names" and just uses email. It also changes the English label "Username" to "Email" in the login form. Finally, it automatically creates a "Nickname" when the user registers. It is an appended email, so "John@doe.com" would be given the automatic nickname "John". This plugin should work on any site. Activate it and set the sidebar widget and you're ready to go. Source: github.com
item.excerpt:encoded: Streamline WordPress' user registration system to login users BEFORE they confirm their emails.

item.title: Setup an AWS Instance
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
Setup an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account. You will need a credit or debit card. If you sign up for 'free tier' this shouldn't cost much or anything. Login to Amazon AWS. Go to the AWS EC2 Management Console. Click Elastic IPs. Click Allocate New Address. Click Allocate. Click Security Groups. Click Create Security Group. Fill in "Security group name" with "SG1". Open these ports with Custom TCP rules:
  • HTTP TCP 80
  • SSH TCP 22
  • HTTPS TCP 443
  • PhantomJS 4444
  • ChromeDriver 9515
Click Save. Click Key Pairs. Click Create Key Pair. Name it "KP1" and create. Click Running Instances. Click Launch Instance. Select the 64bit "Ubuntu Server 16.04 LTS". Select T2 micro. Click Configure Instance Details. Click Next until you get to the "Configure Security Groups" page. Select Select an existing security group. Choose the SG1 group you just created. Click Launch until you get to the "Select a key pair" screen. Select key pair KP1 you just created.

Keywords:

Amazon Web Services instance public/private key pair secure shell (SSH) Elastic IPs [AWS-tut-menu]
item.excerpt:encoded: Instructions to setup an AWS instance.

item.title: Tutorial: Setup cloud based Dev server for PHP / WordPress using Codeception
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
These directions will setup a a Behavior Driven Development (BDD) environment, for WordPress in the cloud using Codeception. You can use this with any cloud provider, and can also be used on an Ubuntu laptop booted off a memory stick. The goal is to simplify WordPress development server deployment.
  1. Setup an Ubuntu instance, i.e. on AWS. You should be able to do this on any cloud based Ubuntu machine or laptop.
  2. Create a local key pair on your machine and connect to your instance. This is the Amazon security authentication system. The goal is a clean Ubuntu machine. You could use another service [like Google or Cloud9] or even a localhost.
  3. Install and update software.

item.title: Types of WordPress automated tests
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
state browser database SUT
WP Acceptance tests carries from test to test assumed headfull JS browser [ie. Selenium with Chrome] not reset after each test entire WP application executed with each browser call
Stateless acceptance tests tests run in isolation assumed headless JS browser [ie. PhantomJS] reset after each test entire WP application executed with each browser call
WP Unit tests tests run in isolation assume no browser or only cURL reset after each test WP application NOT executed
WP API tests tests run in isolation cURL only reset after each test WP application is executed

item.title: Understanding DNS and localhost [vis-a-vi WP-BDD]
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded: The Domain Name System [DNS] is the system a browser uses to resolve domain names like wp-bdd.com to IP addresses like 34.197.171.101. A server connected to the internet generally has one IP address, usually one main domain, but it can also have many subdomains. For instance, this server hosts the domains wp-bdd.com and another blog, messagetothefish.com. Both have the same IP address, but different domain names. When an HTTP or HTTPS request is sent to the server, the request should include the host header which indicates to the server what domain a resonse is expected from. A browser like Chrome or Firefox does this automatically for the user. Internally, once the request is received by the server, a web server, like Apache, sends each request to a particular directory, based on what subdomain is named in the host header. From there, a file is activated, and in our case, passed to the PHP parser. For WordPress, it is called index.php. On most Ubuntu WordPress setups, the main domain root directory is usually set to: //var/www/html/ and subdomains go from there: //var/www/html/sub1/ //var/www/html/sub2/ These are the directories [for their respective domains], which will contain the WordPress root files, especially the index.php, the wp-config.php files, and the other directories like: //var/www/html/wp-admin/ //var/www/html/wp-content/themes/ //var/www/html/wp-content/plugins/ //var/www/html/wp-includes/ Understanding this is important because if you are setting up a local development version of WordPress, you are going to want to be able to set subdomains up. Normally, you'll have a sepearte wp-config.php file for each domain, specifying which database the domain points to. The default setup on Ubuntu, is for the domain localhost to point to //var/www/html . Therefore, to access your local WordPress site, open a browser like Chrome, and got to http://localhost/ and you should get the WordPress install screen. Another consideration is that most forms of testing work the best when you don't have any state. That is, the database is either reset to a starting point, or totally scrubbed after each test. If you're not used to this, you may accidentally delete anything you have on your site, especially if you're using it for anything. My personal setup is that I use http://localhost/ for unit testing, and I have another WordPress install, called http://laptop.dev/ where I have a database that doesn't reset. Directions: Setting up virtual hosts on Ubuntu 16.04 LTS.

item.title: The Feature
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
What is a feature? A feature is any aspect of your software that is useful to you. Anything you can express, that is possible, and that you an afford, can be a feature. A bug is a feature that isn't useful. Since we're talking about development, we're discussing software features that don't exist yet, that we'd like to build [or existing features we'd like to make better]. Often we can describe these things with should statements:
  • It should email all the clients once a month.
  • It should have a setting page in the admin area.
  • It should have a custom post type called GPS coordinates for each subscriber.
  • It should show a timeline of Civil War battles in the footer area.
The bottom line, at some point you have to have a conception of what you want in your mind. This thing is called a feature, and it's what you want your developer to build you.

Git Repo What is TDD/ BDD?

TDD becomes sensible...

Testing vesus Development

Codception architecture

item.title: Mork Gilmartin Conversion Funnel
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
OTC Markers Document

DevOps BDD

Who are the actors?
  • The Closer
  • Mr Slick
  • the Dumplings.\
What are their behaviors? In order to sell financial products, we will convert raw names into phone leads. Efficiency. One role per human.

Mr Slick â telephone man

Main behavior: talk on the phone to produce hot leads Sales job. Must be commission motivated. Start out with one guy until we actually have too many leads developed for him to call. Glen Gary Glen Ross style â¢ 3 people, 2 shifts, 7am â 8pm â¢ $10 / hr + $300 /wk bonus for leader, 2nd place is atta boy, 3rd place is youâre fired Actions: Sits down in front of his computer and clicks "Next". A number shows on the screen, target info, why he's calling the number Makes the call. Selects resolution. For each phone lead, there are general categories and general actions. Probably about a dozen: Lawyers script: We need to hire a lawyer too. Board member script: You can make money from the shares. Secretary script: From one executive assistant to another, hook me up.

Dumplings â computer nerds

Main Behavior: produces action items for Mr Slick $6/hr. 3 people. 4 hour shifts. $72 per shift $216 / day for 9 shifts / 27 man hours Actions: find âtargetâ online drill down from target break out in âpathwaysâ. Pathways are general techniques for doing something. â¢ Enter data into form after each action â¢ Do a basic Google search â¢ Do a search in various specialty databases, pay databases Intelius â¢ Linkdin â¢ Facebook â¢ professional associations â¢ lawyer, accountant, company associations â¢ family â¢ friends â¢ social engineering produces 4 artifacts 1. call object - this is a phone number. A page on the screen containing info on target, and why the phone number is a lead, history 2. email item - an email and a reason, history 3. snail mail item â a snail mail and a history 4. http item â web form and history 3 people at a time work in 4 hour shifts Donât know each other, have assigned roles Gather data on target in organized manner
Target: ACME Gizmo Co. Joe Blow, CEO Phone: (702)555-1212 Josh Abernathy ATTORNEY AT LAW Previously represented company [ ] no answer [x] no connect[ ] rejection[ ] wrong number[ ] busy[ ] tangent[ ] positive SCRIPT: Two reasons weâre calling 1. Looking for Mr. Blow, want to buy his co. youâre close, why not u 2. Weâre going to need a lawyer, and since

item.title: 7 FREE Plugins
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
I will help you build a WordPress plugin - 100% for free - in exchange for letting me blog about the experience.

I'm John Dee - an expert WordPress plugin developer. I am going to be making 7 WordPress plugins for business stakeholders using my Behavior Driven Development / Test Driven Development method. This is an attempt to write a book on WordPress plugin development. I'm looking for business partners who wish to get involved.

My claim

Using BDD / TDD, I can decimate production costs and increase quality for WordPress plugin development. Rough guess, I can reduce costs by 90% at most enterprises.

You get

https://youtu.be/y374wjcTdc0 Directions for the toolkit.
  • A WordPress plugin made for you, which you then own, 100%.
  • A development work-flow for your own team to use in the future.
  • A comparison of your current work flow to other small and medium sized development teams. [Except any proprietary information]

Your requirements

  • You must come up with an IDEA for a WordPress plugin. That's mostly it.
  • You have to pay for programmers. I am a developer - I am an expert programmer who manages other programmers [usually lower skilled, lower paid programmers, but I love working with experts too!]. If you are running an Agile team already, great! If you're a one man shop, great! If you already have programmers or developers, great! This might be a very large cost, or a very small cost, but I promise it will be cheaper by an exponential factor than you can do on your own. Again, I will receive zero percent of this, and I'm not shilling for someone else. I prefer outsourcers, but if you already employ human beings who know PHP, great let's use them!
  • This is for WordPress plugins! Business scripting [which is perfect for WordPress], PHP APIs in general, WP-API, PHP SPAs with WP backend etc.
  • This is for backend plugin development, not frontend theme design. Not content, not hosting - although I'll throw in development hosting if you want it. I use dev servers on AWS, which are nearly free.
  • Assuming this is a business project, you will have to provide for all aspects of your project not specifically related to development. [i.e. if there is a marketing component to your project, you'll need to manage that.]

Workflow

  • One of the main points I'm trying to develop is the ability to work remotely. All work is done via Skype.
  • I will provide development servers. I use cloud based development servers on Amazon AWS domain with some garbage like ec2-34-197-124-101.compute-1.amazonaws.com The main obstacle to doing WordPress BDD is setting up the frameworks. It's really hard. That's what I bring.
  • Code is stored on Github or Bitbucket. If you require a firewall, no problem. I make everything compatible on any site, so I don't need access to your production servers. You can do that.
  • I am doing semi strict TDD / BDD. Programmers DO NOT NEED TO UNDERSTAND TDD IN ADVANCE.
  • I'm doing modified pair programming. I monitor the programmers and direct how they write the code. I generally check in every hour with them. This preserves my brain to take a higher level view of the project while the programmer can work doggedly on the smaller scale without worrying about the higher live architecture.
  • Toolkit is 100% open source, Codeception with WordPress module [PHPUnit etc.]
Contact John Dee to get involved. e. johndeebdd@gmail.com p. (702)748-5491 [call or text]

item.title: WordPress Plugin: Change Admin Email for single site without outbound email, i.e. on localhost
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded: As of WordPress 4.9, the administrator cannot change the site admin email without outgoing email setup on the server, and recipient email credentials. This plugin restores the admin's ability to change this setting without sending a confirmation email. Plugin in the .org repo Plugin on Github https://youtu.be/Uwp8N6zW78U Bonus BDD! As a bonus, for developers I'm distributing some BDD Codeception tests with this plugin. The tests are designed to run via the WordPress module from Codeception. To run them, you'll need composer, selenium, and chrome. To pull the framework, use the instructions here. I use this as an example of running tests in multiple environments. When building this, I used TDD / BDD by creating an acceptance test that worked on v3.9 so that I could run the same test against v4.9. This is overkill, but I wanted to show how to run tests against different environments.

item.title: Running Codeception tests on multiple WordPress environments
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
Suppose you want to run your test suite against multiple environments? Perhaps with different browsers or with different versions of WordPress or PHP? Codeception makes this easy with the --env flag. This is a plugin I made that rolls back a new feature added to WordPress 4.9. I want to run an acceptance test against the latest version of WordPress, and also against a legacy version of WordPress.

Setup multiple environments

I use an Ubuntu laptop with apache2. Your mileage will vary. When I develop a website, say site.com, I setup my laptop to redirect site.dev to a local directory on my laptop. There I keep a copy of the production site to work on. Directions to setup multiple hosts from Rackspace.com On my machine, I setup two distinct WordPress installs, one at http://localhost and the other at http://wp.dev. One running version 4.9 and the other running version 3.9. [caption id="attachment_15527" align="alignnone" width="1366"] WordPress v 3.9.23[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15528" align="alignnone" width="1366"] WordPress v 4.9[/caption] In this example, I'll be running an acceptance test against both versions of WordPress. I'll need to setup the YML file like this: I use this command: bin/codecept run acceptance -vvv --html --env remotehost --env localhost bin/codecept is the executable [might be wpcept or codecept] acceptance is the suite remotehost and localhost are the envs -vvv very very verbose [one dash] --html report to html [two dashes] Codeception runs: [caption id="attachment_15535" align="alignnone" width="1202"] Passing Tests![/caption] https://youtu.be/Uwp8N6zW78U
item.excerpt:encoded: Using the --env flag in Codeception. Running tests against multiple versions of WordPress.

item.title: Roles in WordPress development
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
First of all, the word roles, has several meanings. This article refers to social roles human beings play in relation to one another during development. On a WordPress site, there is a technical concept known as user roles and capabilities. The default ones are subscriber, contributor, editor, and administrator. This article isn't referring to that use of the word roles. Roles can be played by the same person, but usually aren't in direct relation to the size of the project and organization.
  • business stakeholder - [aka the client, the product owner, the guy with the money] - This person wants software. It is from him the requirements flow, and hopefully the money.
  • project manager - [aka "Jobs"] Sharing financial awareness, and responsibility to a budget with the business stakeholder, the PM has overall responsibility for the project, usually including the ability to hire and fire people. This expert can, and must, throttle the efficiency of the project, and therefore should be paid in equity or a salary, not hourly.
  • developer - [aka "Woz"] the developer is a senior programmer. This person must have a global perspective of the project or at least on a major unit of the project. He can be paid a salary or hourly. Rates run from $20 - $150 hr based on experience.
  • architect - [QA architect, senior developer] This person sets up the development environment in conjunction with the PM and the developer. John Dee is an expert in WordPress plugin development architecture and can help you set up yours!
  • programmer - this junior to the developer writes code. He can be "front end" [javascript] or "back end" [PHP] or both. It is appropriate to pay a programmer hourly, or per project. Rates are from, gratis to $25 hr.
  • designer - In WordPress, a "designer" is a person who can modify themes. He can either be skilled at using a graphic page builder, or WYSIWYG editor, or they may know CSS and HTML. You should not employ a designer who cannot produce clean CSS and HTML code. Settings jockeys - designers who don't know how to hard code things - should never be used. Rates are from about $7/hr to $20/hr

item.title: The Toolkit for WordPress BDD
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
https://youtu.be/y374wjcTdc0 To do Behavior Driven Development [BDD] in WordPress, you need to get the tools! Here is the stack you should use:

Operating System

Ubuntu 16 LTS. I personally use an Ubuntu 17 development server on my laptop. You can run Ubuntu on most machines with a USB memory stick, and it's free. I use Ubuntu on the Amzaon AWS remote cloud servers and production servers. Ubuntu is a brand, but it's just a Debian based Linux distro, so it's future proof. If you stopped liking Ubuntu, you could switch to another distro without hassel.

Get the stack

Once you have a machine with Ubuntu running, you can load the entire development stack by running a single command: source <(curl -s https://raw.githubusercontent.com/johndeebdd/Remote-BDD-Setup/master/installScripts/wordpress.sh) Directions

Test Framework

Codeception with WordPress modules - PHPunit is the standard and default library for doing unit testing in PHP. CodeCeption INCLUDES PHPunit, as well as a whole series of libraries for doing BDD.

Acceptance testing

You should use the WPWebDriver and WPDb modules. You can use Selenium to drive a full browser if you want, but generally you should use PhantomJS, because it is much faster. You can write your test in the Gherkin format, or in procedural PHP. Generally, I consider Gherkin cumbersome and not worth the candle. Sample acceptance.yml

WP-Unit testing

You should use the WPloader and WPQueries modules. Sample unit.yml

Where does code live?

Use a Git repo. Use Github for code that has a public face. Use Bitbucket for private repos [or pay Github for a private repo, either way].

How do you control outsourcer Git commit access?

First setup a few emails: freelancer1@yourdomain.com, freelancer2@yourdomain.com etc. These accounts are granted direct commit access to the repo. Give the outsourcer access to the email account. The repo itself can set a webhook to pull to the production server upon commit. When you want to freeze the outsourcer from the project, you just change the password on Github and email accounts. The project manager retains access to pull to production. The outsourcer can make a commit and it appears directly on the development server. When the commit is approved by the project manager, he does a manual pull to the production machine.

How does the outsourcer work on the code?

Some programmers will have their own IDE setups that they like and know how to use. Eclipse is the best free IDE, while PHPStorm is probably the best commercial IDE. If they know how to pull down from Github and run the code on a local host, great. If they don't know how to do that, setup a development server in the cloud for them. Our stack include the Codiad IDE, which is an open source IDE similar to PHPStorm. TO access it, just go to /codiad/ on your development server, it's all setup already.

How do you run the test suite?

cd /var/www/html/wp-content/plugins/{project dir} bin/codecept run -vvv --html

How do I see the test results?

They appear in the terminal, or at http://yourdomain.com/wp-content/plugins/{project dir}/tests/_output/ Usually in the terminal you can use the up arrow shortcut.

How do I commit to the repo?

git add --all git commit -m "some kind of message!" git push origin master

How do I log in to the WordPress site?

You can log in by using the FastRegister plugin. Just enter an email in the sidebar form and viola! You're logged in as an admin.

How do I log in to a terminal?

The stack will preconfigured a user called "freelancer" with a password "password". Just SSH into the system without a pem file.

item.title: How to find the best possible WordPress plugins
item.dc:creator: John Dee
item.content:encoded:
Post this template as a guaranteed contest on upwork.com or freelancer.com for $40.
******** Recommend and install a WordPress plugin ********* I want to install a WordPress plugin, but I'm not sure exactly which one I should use. Give me a very brief overview of what WordPress plugin(s) I should use, how much it will cost me (if anything), and what functionality it has. I'm not looking for a comprehensive overview of WordPress plugins, I'm looking for a specific plugin and someone who can execute installing it. You don't need to submit credentials or previous projects, just know how to use the plugin you recommend and be able to install and set up the functionality. Submit a simple text entry describing what plugin I should use, and you're contact information. I will provide you with access. This is a guaranteed contest. Functionality I need: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
item.excerpt:encoded: How to find the best WordPress plugins
